attributes.title: Weathering the Storm: Discordant Learning about Reputations for Reliability

q1.value: Weathering the Storm: Discordant Learning about Reputations for Reliability

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This research focuses on reputations for reliability in alliance behavior. A reputation for reliability is posed as information regarding the likelihood that a state follows through with its alliance commitments. We anticipate that reputation change follows a Bayesian process where reputation acts as a prior while new observation of the state’s behavior act as additional data. The observer then updates the prior using the new data to develop a posterior belief regarding the state’s behavior (an updated reputation). Whether or not there is a change in the quality (good or bad) of a reputation, therefore, depends on the new observations. For the purposes of this theory, let us divide this information into two types: congruent and incongruent. Congruent information, the observation of behavior that is in line with the prior, results in a posterior belief that is in agreement with the prior belief. For ease of interpretation, a state that has a good reputation for reliability and that demonstrates that reliability in the present will continue to have a good reputation for reliability.

q16.value: Hypothesis 1a: In minor crises, good reputations act as good will reservoirs that will sustain the positive reputation of the state. Hypothesis 1b: In minor crises, states with a middling reputation will suﬀer a loss in reputation. Hypothesis 2a: In major crises, all states will suﬀer a loss of reputation. Hypothesis 2b: A state with a good reputation for reliability will suﬀer a greater decrease in reputation than states with middling reputations.

q17.value: We will employ a survey experiment using the Mechanical Turk infrastructure.

q21.value: This is the pilot which will help inform the power analysis moving forward.

q2.value: Harry Kennard | Gesche Margarethe Huebner | David Shipworth

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: This study is motivated by questions around the impacts of cold domestic conditions on health. In the UK, the primary evidence for a link between cold and poor health is the peak in mortality which occurs in winter, as recorded in excess winter mortality statistics. To date, there have been a limited number of large scale studies into the population level links between cold exposure and health. The study makes use of UK Biobank data, and in particular temperature data taken from an wristband activity monitor worn by over 100,000 Biobank participants for a week. Pilot studies showed that the temperature recorded by the wristband is a determined by a mixture of ambient environmental temperature and heat from the wrist – a quantity which has been called ‘experienced temperature’ – a concept adapted from Kuras et al. (2015). Following a large data processing exercise to down-sample the 100k data files to produce the experienced temperature time series, associations between demographics/health condition data and the experienced temperature will be tested.

q16.value: 1) No significant differences in experienced will be measured as a function of demographics. 2) A weak association between low experienced temperature and health conditions associated with excess winter deaths is expected. 3) A stronger association between low experienced temperature and health conditions associated with excess winter deaths and low household income.

attributes.title: Conjoint analysis on job choice in Sweden

q1.value: Conjoint analysis on job choice in Sweden

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This pre-analysis plan describes data collection and empirical methods for a survey experiment on job choice. The target population is employed people on the Swedish labor market. The experiment will be fielded within the Citizen Panel (https://lore.gu.se/surveys/citizen) and has the purpose of quantifying relative preferences across job traits for men and women. We are particularly interested in the working environment as a job trait, and how men and women value a working environment free from sexual harassment. The overarching goal is to study the causes of gender segregation and gender wage gaps, and the project is funded by the Swedish Research Council for Health, Working Life and Welfare (www.forte.se/en).

q16.value: See C1. See pre-analysis plan for subsample analysis and validation tests.

q17.value: Using a conjoint experiment in an online convenience sample

q19.value: We will sample 5,667 respondents and expect approximately 3,400 responses

q27.value: The survey will be fielded within the Citizen Panel (https://lore.gu.se/surveys/citizen), and carried our by the Citizen Panel

attributes.title: Shared social identity and strategic uncertainty

q1.value: Shared social identity and strategic uncertainty

q2.value: Dominik Duell | Catherine Hafer | Dimitri Landa

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Frequently groups face collective action problems. Several studies have suggested that solving such problems is easier for groups that are more homogenous, that is, for groups in which most individuals share a social identity, and often that finding is explained by a greater individual willingness to benefit in-group members (among others, Fersthman/Gneezy 2001, Fowler/Kam 2007). A few studies consider other mechanisms by which greater group homogeneity results in more successful collective action (e.g., through superior shared technology, see Habyarimana/Humphreys/Posner/Weinstein 2007). We propose that strategic uncertainty may drive this phenomenon: Collective action often requires that individuals coordinate on taking an action that is costly with certainty, but that yields benefits only if enough others take similar actions. Individuals in more homogenous groups may face less uncertainty regarding how other groups members will behave, i.e. they may be more confident that enough of their fellow group members will also take the risky action, making them more willing to take the risky action themselves. We aim to distinguish this mechanism from the mechanism in which individuals’ preferences for benefiting those who share one’s social identity, or to hurt those who do not, drives the increased propensity to take the risky action in more homogeneous groups (as laid out in previous studies). We also investigate a mechanism where shared social identity implies shared beliefs about fellow in-group members’ types (i.e., risk preferences). We implement a laboratory experiment consisting of three stages. In stage 1, we elicit what subjects deem their two most important social group memberships and then, depending on a random draw, either assign subjects based on those stated social identities into two social identity groups of similar subjects or assign them randomly into two social identity groups (called “Klees” and “Kandinskys”). Subjects know that both assignment procedures are possible; they are not told that the probability assigned to the random procedure is .99. In stage 2, subjects retain the social identities from stage 1 but are assigned to decision groups of either size 2, 3, or 4. Decision groups may consist of individuals with different social identities. Each decision group then plays a stag hunt game: Each subject in each decision group chooses between two options “W” and “R”. If all subjects in the decision group play W, everyone receives a payoff w, while if all subjects play R, everyone receives a payoff r. If subjects in a decision group do not coordinate on one option, those who play W receive a payoff x and those who play R receive a payoff y, where w>r>y>x. Subjects choose between option W and R for each of 20 rounds, and they are randomly re-matched into decision groups in each round. In some sessions, they are assigned to groups of size 2 or 3, and in some other sessions they are assigned to groups of 4, where the ratio of group members of one social identity to those of another is either 2:2 or 3:1. In stage 3, we elicit subjects’ risk preferences using the Bomb Game and elicit their beliefs about the average risk preference in either their social identity in-group or social identity out-group (between subject design).

q16.value: We test whether subjects are more likely to choose the welfare optimizing but more risky action W across different group sizes (2, 3, or 4) and social identity group composition (more homogeneous, more diverse). In particular, we test the claim that H1: Individuals are more likely to choose a welfare-maximizing, risky option in a group coordination game when the group is more homogeneous in social identity (Less strategic uncertainty mechanism). H2: Individuals are less likely to choose the a welfare-maximizing, risky option in a group coordination game when the group contains fewer members of the individual’s social identity group (Preference mechanism). H3: Individuals are more likely to choose a welfare-maximizing, risky option in a group coordination game when they belief those who share their social identity hold more similar risk preferences like themselves (Same type mechanism).

q17.value: We test our hypotheses by looking at individuals’ rate of taking the risky action W. In particular, we look at decision groups of 3 that either feature, from the perspective of a given subject, two subjects with shared social identity (3-2in), one other subject with shared social identity (3-1in), or two other subjects with a different social identity (3-2out). And, we look at decision groups of 4 that either feature, from the perspective of a given subject, two subjects with a shared social identity (4-2in), one other subject with a shared social identity (4-1in), or three other subjects with a different social identity (4-3out). Evidence for H1 is provided by observing no difference in E, averaging across all subjects, in 3-2in vs 3-1in and in 4-2in vs 4-3out but higher E in 4-2in or 4-3out vs 4-1in. Such pattern would indicate that more homogeneous groups, in terms of social identity, feature less strategic uncertainty but when the level of homogeneity is constant, behavior does not change. Evidence for H2 is provided when we find E decreasing in the number of group members who do not share the individual’s identity, indicating a willingness to hurt the social out-group. Note, our design precludes any strategies that are driven by in-group favoritism is possible. Evidence for H3 is assessed by correlating E, between subject, and the difference between subjects’ risk preferences and their beliefs about others’ risk preferences. We implement proper independent or pair difference-in-means or difference-in-distribution tests as well as a regression including E, group composition, subjects’ risk preferences, and beliefs about risk preferences of others. In a pilot study conducted in 2018 (par group sizes of 4), we learned that in groups of 2, E is higher when subjects interact with someone who shares their identity, that E is higher in groups of 2 than groups of 3, and that switching Stage 2 and 3 does not affect results in Stage 2.

attributes.title: Constitutional territorial reforms in polarized contexts. Experimental evidence from Spain and Catalonia.

q1.value: Constitutional territorial reforms in polarized contexts. Experimental evidence from Spain and Catalonia.

q5.value: This work was supported by the James Madison Trust [Project Federalism in Polarised contexts]; the Senior Talento Fellowship [2019/00029/001] and the Spanish Ministry of Economy, Industry and Competitiveness [CSO2017-82881-R].

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Until very recently, Spain was considered among scholars as one of the successful cases of federalism. The decentralization of the state in the aftermath of the Francoist dictatorship (1939-1976) – with the creation of the State of Autonomies - served to consolidate transition to democracy and appease territorial tensions during more than three decades. This model has been recently challenged by the raise of secessionist demands in Catalonia since the mid-2000s, increasing political polarisation and a convoluted political period during which the Catalan government declared independence following the celebration of an illegal referendum. The central government responded to the declaration of independence with the suspension regional autonomy (invoking article 155 in the Constitution), the imprisonment of some of the Catalan leaders and the call for a new regional election. Following the celebration of elections in December 21st 2017, Catalan political parties were unable to put forward a successful candidate to the vote of investiture for more than four months. The deadlock ended on may 17th 2018 with the investiture of a new Catalan president. The appeasement of the Catalan crisis is not likely to happen in the short-run. Political polarization in Catalonia largely complicates bargaining among Catalan political parties and between national representatives and Catalan leaders. In a polarised context compromise might become highly contested by sectors of the electorate that interpret it as a humiliated defeat. Political polarization around the territorial/identity debate has also permeated national politics. The two most important state-wide parties that compete for the hegemony of the right-wing bloc (Partido Popular and Ciudadanos) largely base their electoral appeal among centrist and right-wing voters in a hardliner stance that forbids any sort of political bargaining to sort out the Catalan crisis. In addition, electoral politics do not help to appease the escalation of demands. There is an underlying electoral competition among Catalan secessionist parties to become the hegemonic actor within the pro-independence bloc. That turns the bargaining process about the formation of government into a sort of Prisoner’s Dilemma. As a result, even if a majority of party leaders were moderate pragmatists (which does not correspond with the actual balance of powers between hardliners and softliners within the secessionist bloc, which tips towards the former group), no one has incentives to be the first one to show the moderate flag within the pro-independence bloc, fearing that the might be accused of being responsible of the “watering down” of the secessionist demands. However, despite the termination of the Catalan conflict being far away, it is very likely that its resolution involves institutional changes in the Spanish State of Autonomies. A large majority of citizens in Catalonia support a modification of the “statu-quo”, such as some form of symbolic recognition of the Catalan “nationhood”, a modification of fiscal intergovernmental arrangements (revenue powers) and further executive powers transferred to the Catalan government. It might also involve changes that deepen the federal nature of the Spanish State of Autonomies. A majority of Spanish citizens support a Constitutional reform as a way to appease conflict in Catalonia (but we ignore which types of constitutional reforms they specifically support). Although institutional arrangements will be at the core of the intergovernmental bargaining process that might put an end to the Catalan political crisis, so far we lack a detailed analysis of the specific areas of the Spanish territorial model that both Spanish and Catalan citizens are willing to reform and in what direction. In addition, we know little about the preferences of the citizens of the state where secessionist pressures are developing, as studies on secessionism are usually focused on the drivers of the secessionist debate in the separatist region. This project advances the literature by exploring Catalan public opinion in comparison with Spanish public opinion. More specifically, the analysis is organized around two parts: a) Part 1: we explore preferences for a new constitutional territorial deal among Catalan and Spanish public opinion. We analyze preferences for different constitutional deals using a conjoint analysis. The dependent variable is support towards a new constitutional territorial deal based on specific institutional characteristics. b) Part 2: we analyze the level of polarization around the territorial issue in Spain and Catalonia. The “state” of polarization in a given context is more difficult to define than the “trend” in polarization (see Fiorina and Abrams (2008:567). A way to evaluate the “level” of polarization is to explore the extent to which views can be moderated. This can be done using experimental evidence. In this project we analyze the “elasticity” of preferences towards the territorial organization of both Spanish and Catalan public opinion when they are exposed to the political and economic costs of the current conflict. We will explore the impact of both political costs and economic costs upon the territorial organization of the state using a survey experiment. The dependent variable is degree of decentralization of the preferred territorial model.

q16.value: As detailed above, the research project has two distinctive parts. We specify below the set of hypotheses for each part. PART 1 Hypotheses related to preferences towards a new constitutional deal: H1. Individuals’ preferences for a new constitutional deal will be less driven by shared-rule characteristics of the deal (Senate or intergovernmental relations) than by its economic characteristics (infrastructures, regional financing), the regulation of identity issues (language) or self-rule (level of competences). H2. Individuals’ preferences for a new constitutional deal will be conditional upon individuals’ ideology and identity. H2a. Leftwing individuals will exhibit higher support for pro-decentralization constitutional deals than rightwing individuals. H2b. Individuals with stronger Spanish identity will exhibit higher support for pro-centralization deals, while individuals with more regionalist identity will exhibit higher support for more pro-decentralization deals. H3. Ideology will have a stronger effect in predicting preferences for a new constitutional deal among Spanish public opinion than among Catalan public opinion. PART 2 Hypotheses related to levels of polarization. H1. We expect exposure to the costs of the territorial conflict to moderate preferences towards the territorial organization of the State. H1a. In Spain we expect individuals who are exposed to the costs of the conflict to exhibit less centralizing preferences towards the territorial model of the State than individuals who are not exposed to the costs. H1b. In Catalonia we expect individuals who are exposed to the costs of the conflict to exhibit less decentralizing preferences towards the territorial model of the State than individuals who are not exposed to the costs. H2. We expect individuals that are exposed to the costs of the territorial conflict to be more willing to find a solution to the territorial conflict than individuals who are not exposed to costs. H3. We expect the effect of costs upon preferences to follow a u-inverted shape: the effect of being exposed to the costs will be higher among individuals with less extreme positions in the territorial debate than among individuals with more extreme positions. H4. We expect the effect of treatments to vary across types of costs. More specifically, we expect economic costs of the territorial conflict to have a higher impact in moderating individuals’ preferences than political costs. H5. We expect exposure to costs to have a higher impact in the Spanish sample than in the Catalan sample.

q17.value: We will analyse the preferences of Catalan and Spanish public opinion upon different sets of “devolution” arrangements through the use conjoint analysis and a survey experiment. a) Conjoint analysis. Conjoint analysis helps to analyse how people value different attributes in a given proposal. In the case of this research, the proposal will be a constitutional deal that include a list of potential institutional reforms (devo-deals). In particular, individuals will be asked to choose among different constitutional deals that define a territorial model seven areas: regional financing, regional infrastructures, regulation of language, intergovernmental relations, role of Senate, definition of the region in the constitution and decentralization of competences. Individuals are asked to choose among pairs of constitutional deals that vary regarding the level of decentralization in each of the previous areas. Our goal is to use the conjoint analysis to determine what particular combination of attributes show the strongest effect upon the preferred constitutional reforms made by respondents. We will also analyze which deals are accepted by a majority of the Spanish and only-Catalan samples to study which are the possible compromises that can be accepted by a majority of both parts of the conflict. Dependent variable: selection a constitutional deal (choosing six times among 2 different constitutional deals) b) Survey experiment. We will use a survey experiment in which we divide the sample in Catalonia and the sample in Spain in three groups: a control group, a treated group A that is exposed to the political costs of the territorial conflict and a treated group B that is exposed to the economic costs of the territorial conflict. We then asks respondents about their preferences over the territorial organization of the state, which will represent our main dependent variable. Dependent variable 1: maximum level of decentralization that the respondent would support in the Spanish territorial model (0-10 scale, where 0 means full centralization, 5 means current model and 10 means independence). Dependent variable 2: minimum level of decentralization that the respondent would support in the Spanish territorial model (0-10 scale, where 0 means full centralization, 5 means current model and 10 means independence). Dependent variable 3: Difference between DV1-DV2 (maximum level of decentralization – minimum level of decentralization). Dependent variable 4a_h: Support (0-10) to different measures to end territorial conflict (8 measures ranging from measure a to measure h) Dependent variable 5: level of priority that sorting out the territorial conflict should have in the political agenda (0-10).

q19.value: A sample of 1500 citizens in Spain (including Catalonia as part of the Spanish sample); A sample of 1500 citizens in Catalonia.

q27.value: The survey is fielded and implemented by NETQUEST SOLUTIONS.

registration_responses.q1: Constitutional territorial reforms in polarized contexts. Experimental evidence from Spain and Catalonia.
registration_responses.q5: This work was supported by the James Madison Trust [Project Federalism in Polarised contexts]; the Senior Talento Fellowship [2019/00029/001] and the Spanish Ministry of Economy, Industry and Competitiveness [CSO2017-82881-R].
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data
registration_responses.q15: Until very recently, Spain was considered among scholars as one of the successful cases of federalism. The decentralization of the state in the aftermath of the Francoist dictatorship (1939-1976) – with the creation of the State of Autonomies - served to consolidate transition to democracy and appease territorial tensions during more than three decades. This model has been recently challenged by the raise of secessionist demands in Catalonia since the mid-2000s, increasing political polarisation and a convoluted political period during which the Catalan government declared independence following the celebration of an illegal referendum. The central government responded to the declaration of independence with the suspension regional autonomy (invoking article 155 in the Constitution), the imprisonment of some of the Catalan leaders and the call for a new regional election. Following the celebration of elections in December 21st 2017, Catalan political parties were unable to put forward a successful candidate to the vote of investiture for more than four months. The deadlock ended on may 17th 2018 with the investiture of a new Catalan president. The appeasement of the Catalan crisis is not likely to happen in the short-run. Political polarization in Catalonia largely complicates bargaining among Catalan political parties and between national representatives and Catalan leaders. In a polarised context compromise might become highly contested by sectors of the electorate that interpret it as a humiliated defeat. Political polarization around the territorial/identity debate has also permeated national politics. The two most important state-wide parties that compete for the hegemony of the right-wing bloc (Partido Popular and Ciudadanos) largely base their electoral appeal among centrist and right-wing voters in a hardliner stance that forbids any sort of political bargaining to sort out the Catalan crisis. In addition, electoral politics do not help to appease the escalation of demands. There is an underlying electoral competition among Catalan secessionist parties to become the hegemonic actor within the pro-independence bloc. That turns the bargaining process about the formation of government into a sort of Prisoner’s Dilemma. As a result, even if a majority of party leaders were moderate pragmatists (which does not correspond with the actual balance of powers between hardliners and softliners within the secessionist bloc, which tips towards the former group), no one has incentives to be the first one to show the moderate flag within the pro-independence bloc, fearing that the might be accused of being responsible of the “watering down” of the secessionist demands. However, despite the termination of the Catalan conflict being far away, it is very likely that its resolution involves institutional changes in the Spanish State of Autonomies. A large majority of citizens in Catalonia support a modification of the “statu-quo”, such as some form of symbolic recognition of the Catalan “nationhood”, a modification of fiscal intergovernmental arrangements (revenue powers) and further executive powers transferred to the Catalan government. It might also involve changes that deepen the federal nature of the Spanish State of Autonomies. A majority of Spanish citizens support a Constitutional reform as a way to appease conflict in Catalonia (but we ignore which types of constitutional reforms they specifically support). Although institutional arrangements will be at the core of the intergovernmental bargaining process that might put an end to the Catalan political crisis, so far we lack a detailed analysis of the specific areas of the Spanish territorial model that both Spanish and Catalan citizens are willing to reform and in what direction. In addition, we know little about the preferences of the citizens of the state where secessionist pressures are developing, as studies on secessionism are usually focused on the drivers of the secessionist debate in the separatist region. This project advances the literature by exploring Catalan public opinion in comparison with Spanish public opinion. More specifically, the analysis is organized around two parts: a) Part 1: we explore preferences for a new constitutional territorial deal among Catalan and Spanish public opinion. We analyze preferences for different constitutional deals using a conjoint analysis. The dependent variable is support towards a new constitutional territorial deal based on specific institutional characteristics. b) Part 2: we analyze the level of polarization around the territorial issue in Spain and Catalonia. The “state” of polarization in a given context is more difficult to define than the “trend” in polarization (see Fiorina and Abrams (2008:567). A way to evaluate the “level” of polarization is to explore the extent to which views can be moderated. This can be done using experimental evidence. In this project we analyze the “elasticity” of preferences towards the territorial organization of both Spanish and Catalan public opinion when they are exposed to the political and economic costs of the current conflict. We will explore the impact of both political costs and economic costs upon the territorial organization of the state using a survey experiment. The dependent variable is degree of decentralization of the preferred territorial model.
registration_responses.q16: As detailed above, the research project has two distinctive parts. We specify below the set of hypotheses for each part. PART 1 Hypotheses related to preferences towards a new constitutional deal: H1. Individuals’ preferences for a new constitutional deal will be less driven by shared-rule characteristics of the deal (Senate or intergovernmental relations) than by its economic characteristics (infrastructures, regional financing), the regulation of identity issues (language) or self-rule (level of competences). H2. Individuals’ preferences for a new constitutional deal will be conditional upon individuals’ ideology and identity. H2a. Leftwing individuals will exhibit higher support for pro-decentralization constitutional deals than rightwing individuals. H2b. Individuals with stronger Spanish identity will exhibit higher support for pro-centralization deals, while individuals with more regionalist identity will exhibit higher support for more pro-decentralization deals. H3. Ideology will have a stronger effect in predicting preferences for a new constitutional deal among Spanish public opinion than among Catalan public opinion. PART 2 Hypotheses related to levels of polarization. H1. We expect exposure to the costs of the territorial conflict to moderate preferences towards the territorial organization of the State. H1a. In Spain we expect individuals who are exposed to the costs of the conflict to exhibit less centralizing preferences towards the territorial model of the State than individuals who are not exposed to the costs. H1b. In Catalonia we expect individuals who are exposed to the costs of the conflict to exhibit less decentralizing preferences towards the territorial model of the State than individuals who are not exposed to the costs. H2. We expect individuals that are exposed to the costs of the territorial conflict to be more willing to find a solution to the territorial conflict than individuals who are not exposed to costs. H3. We expect the effect of costs upon preferences to follow a u-inverted shape: the effect of being exposed to the costs will be higher among individuals with less extreme positions in the territorial debate than among individuals with more extreme positions. H4. We expect the effect of treatments to vary across types of costs. More specifically, we expect economic costs of the territorial conflict to have a higher impact in moderating individuals’ preferences than political costs. H5. We expect exposure to costs to have a higher impact in the Spanish sample than in the Catalan sample.
registration_responses.q17: We will analyse the preferences of Catalan and Spanish public opinion upon different sets of “devolution” arrangements through the use conjoint analysis and a survey experiment. a) Conjoint analysis. Conjoint analysis helps to analyse how people value different attributes in a given proposal. In the case of this research, the proposal will be a constitutional deal that include a list of potential institutional reforms (devo-deals). In particular, individuals will be asked to choose among different constitutional deals that define a territorial model seven areas: regional financing, regional infrastructures, regulation of language, intergovernmental relations, role of Senate, definition of the region in the constitution and decentralization of competences. Individuals are asked to choose among pairs of constitutional deals that vary regarding the level of decentralization in each of the previous areas. Our goal is to use the conjoint analysis to determine what particular combination of attributes show the strongest effect upon the preferred constitutional reforms made by respondents. We will also analyze which deals are accepted by a majority of the Spanish and only-Catalan samples to study which are the possible compromises that can be accepted by a majority of both parts of the conflict. Dependent variable: selection a constitutional deal (choosing six times among 2 different constitutional deals) b) Survey experiment. We will use a survey experiment in which we divide the sample in Catalonia and the sample in Spain in three groups: a control group, a treated group A that is exposed to the political costs of the territorial conflict and a treated group B that is exposed to the economic costs of the territorial conflict. We then asks respondents about their preferences over the territorial organization of the state, which will represent our main dependent variable. Dependent variable 1: maximum level of decentralization that the respondent would support in the Spanish territorial model (0-10 scale, where 0 means full centralization, 5 means current model and 10 means independence). Dependent variable 2: minimum level of decentralization that the respondent would support in the Spanish territorial model (0-10 scale, where 0 means full centralization, 5 means current model and 10 means independence). Dependent variable 3: Difference between DV1-DV2 (maximum level of decentralization – minimum level of decentralization). Dependent variable 4a_h: Support (0-10) to different measures to end territorial conflict (8 measures ranging from measure a to measure h) Dependent variable 5: level of priority that sorting out the territorial conflict should have in the political agenda (0-10).
registration_responses.q19: A sample of 1500 citizens in Spain (including Catalonia as part of the Spanish sample); A sample of 1500 citizens in Catalonia.
registration_responses.q27: The survey is fielded and implemented by NETQUEST SOLUTIONS.

attributes.title: Neighbourhoods and local public goods: evidence from a housing lottery

q1.value: Neighbourhoods and local public goods: evidence from a housing lottery

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Urban policy affects how people of different backgrounds live in close proximity. This is particularly true in the case of government housing policies, where the allocation of households to new housing blocks can affect the composition of new neighborhoods. This study studies the effect of household composition in new housing buildings to the production of local public goods in, and around, those buildings. See full pre-analysis plan for more detail.

q16.value: How are local public goods in public housing, produced by communities at the level of the building, affected by the composition of those communities, along three key dimensions: 1) the poverty rate of the community, 2) the ethnic fractionalization of that community, and 3) and the share of owner-occupiers living in the building. See full pre-analysis plan for more detail.

q17.value: I use a natural experiment in which households are randomly assigned to new housing blocks to test for the effect of community composition (measured among households before they moved into new built housing) on public goods. I measure public goods with household surveys with residents of the new buildings, and with specially designed building survey, based on systematic observation of the local amenities around buildings. See full pre-analysis plan for more detail.

q25.value: “Self-certification” in July of 2015, full committee review received in 12th December 2017.

registration_responses.q1: Neighbourhoods and local public goods: evidence from a housing lottery
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

This study studies the effect of household composition in new housing buildings to the production of local public goods in, and around, those buildings. See full pre-analysis plan for more detail.

See full pre-analysis plan for more detail.
registration_responses.q25: “Self-certification” in July of 2015, full committee review received in 12th December 2017.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: We are testing whether and how the gender of a speaker affects his / her political persuasiveness. To do this, we are running a survey experiment which varies the gender (through name, voice, and photo) of two hypothetical political candidates having a debate on four issue areas. We randomize which position the speaker takes, such that treatment effects will estimate the effect of speaker gender on the persuasiveness of the exact same argument for each issue area.

q16.value: Our hypotheses are straight forward: H1: Respondents will be more likely to agree with policies articulated by the male candidate in gender neutral policy areas (in our case tourism) and male-gendered policy areas (terrorism and national security) H2: Respondents will be more likely to agree with policies articulated by the female candidate in female-gendered policy areas (children’s health) and in policy areas related to women’s interests (over-the-counter birth control). H3: Effects will be strongest among those with the lowest levels of political efficacy and least personal experience in each issue area.

q17.value: We are running a survey experiment that varies the gender of the speaker (by name, photo, and voice) for each candidate. For each issue area, treatment effects will be estimated as the different levels of agreement / perceived persuasiveness between the male and female speaker.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

We randomize which position the speaker takes, such that treatment effects will estimate the effect of speaker gender on the persuasiveness of the exact same argument for each issue area.

H3: Effects will be strongest among those with the lowest levels of political efficacy and least personal experience in each issue area.
registration_responses.q17: We are running a survey experiment that varies the gender of the speaker (by name, photo, and voice) for each candidate. For each issue area, treatment effects will be estimated as the different levels of agreement / perceived persuasiveness between the male and female speaker.

attributes.title: In God we Act: Exposure to the Prosperity Gospel as a Stimulant of Political Participation

q1.value: In God we Act: Exposure to the Prosperity Gospel as a Stimulant of Political Participation

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: The study aims to test how exposure to messages typical of the so-called prosperity gospel movement within Christianity affects worshipers' political attitudes and behaviors. Due both to research challenges (because it transcends denominations, prosperity gospel exposure is difficult to pinpoint) and the nature of the theology (because of its entrepreneurial zeal for expanding one’s following, many prosperity preachers have tended to shy away from overt political rhetoric), the prosperity gospel has been understudied in the political communication literature. Existing research (which has tended to narrowly employ survey methodology) has posited two, conflicting ideas about how prosperity gospel exposure might affect worshippers: (1) its individualist message will disincline worshipers from getting involved in politics by downplaying the perceived role of the communal; or (2) its self-affirming message will increase internal efficacy and hence increase worshipers’ inclinations to participate in politics. Herein lies my research question: How does exposure to messages typical of the prosperity gospel movement affect individuals’ political attitudes and behavior? Building on researched McClendon and Riedl (2015) conducted in Kenya, this experiment is designed to evaluate whether audio messages pieced together from Christian sermons have an effect on political ideology, partisan preference, intent to vote and internal efficacy.

q16.value: The principal hypotheses to be tested are that exposure to the prosperity gospel treatment audio clip will increase internal efficacy, conservative ideology, affinity toward the Republican Party and intent to vote, compared to the placebo case and to the social gospel treatment case.

q17.value: I will estimate differences in means between the prosperity treatment, the social treatment and the placebo conditions for each of the seven data outcome measures: (1) internal efficacy (measured on a five-point scale); (2) intent to vote in the 2020 presidential elections; (3) choice to click on links offering Election Day resources; (4) party feeling thermometers; (5) candidate preference; (6) question on role of government; and (7) question on government regulation versus free market. For each of the seven regression models, post-treatment dependent variables will be measured with indicator variables for the two treatments and placebo condition. For all regression estimates, I will report 95 percent confidence intervals for the average treatment effect. I will call estimates with p-values less than 0.05 “significant.” When interpreting results, I will rely primarily on the covariate-adjusted estimates. I will also explore heterogeneous effects by conducting regression analysis separately for six subgroups made up of self-identified Republicans, Democrats and Independents and those low and high in political knowledge, as well as for non-self-identified Christians and self-identified Christians.
